intro: Eleocharis olivacea, commonly known as the olive sedge, is a species of flowering plant in the family Cyperaceae. It is a perennial herb that typically grows in wetland habitats, including marshes and pond margins. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, clustered spikelets that are often pale green or brown. It is characterized by its ability to thrive in saturated soils and is often found in temperate regions. Eleocharis olivacea plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various aquatic and semi-aquatic organisms.
